Name: A/B Testing
Definition: Testing "that allows testers to determine which of two systems or components performs better" (IEEE, 2022, p. 1)
Parent(s): Statistical Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 1, 35)
Notes: "Not a test case generation technique as test inputs are not generated"; "us[es] the existing system as a partial oracle" (IEEE, 2022, p. 36)

Name: Acceptance Testing
Approach Category: Level (IEEE, 2022, pp. 12, 21-22, 26-27; 2017, p. 467; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: "Testing conducted to enable a user, customer, or other authorized entity to determine whether to accept a system or component" and whether it "satisfies its acceptance criteria" and/or "the contractual requirements are met" (IEEE, 2017, p. 5)
Parent(s): System Testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 439)
Synonym(s): Qualification Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-6), AT (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)
Notes: "May or may not involve the developers of the system" (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-6), but "usually performed by the purchaser … with the … vendor" (IEEE, 2017, p. 5). Related to usability testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 439) and validation testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 5). Note that IEEE (2017, p. 5) makes a distinction between "acceptance testing" and "an acceptance test"

Name: Accessibility Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, pp. 1, 22; implied by its quality)
Definition: Testing "used to measure the degree to which a test item can be operated by users with the widest possible range of characteristics and abilities" (IEEE, 2022, p. 1; 2013, p. 2) "to achieve a specified goal in a specified context of use" (ISO/IEC, 2011)
Parent(s): Usability Testing (IEEE, 2022, p.1 [although listed separately on p. 22]; ISO/IEC, 2011)
Notes: Good to use when the software will be widely available or when it will be used by people with disabilities (IEEE, 2022, p. 45)

Name: Ad Hoc Reviews
Definition: Reviews "performed informally without a structured process" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Reviews
Notes: See ISO 20246

Name: Ad Hoc Testing
Definition: Testing where "test cases are derived by relying on the software engineer’s skill, intuition, and experience with similar programs" to "identify[] test cases that are not easily generated by more formalized techniques" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14) "performed without test analysis [or] test design" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Experience-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14); Informal Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Adaptive Random Testing
Definition: Random testing "in which other input selection criteria direct the random input sampling" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Parent(s): Random Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Notes: Kind of a vague definition; what are these criteria?

Name: Adversarial Testing
Definition: Testing "based on the attempted creation and execution of adversarial examples [("input[s] to an ML model … that result[] in the model outputting an incorrect result with high confidence")] to identify defects in an ML model" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): ML Model Testing
Notes: See ISO 29119-11

Name: Agile Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29)
Definition: Testing performed in the context of the agile development model "based on iterative development, frequent inspection and adaptation, and incremental deliveries" (IEEE, 2017, p. 15; OG ISO/IEC, 2016)
Parent(s): Continuous Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29; implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 9-6), Lifecycle-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-5; OG [2, 3, 10]), DevOps Testing? (implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-7; OG [11]), Incremental Testing?
Notes: Test cases drive development (Washizaki, 2024, p. 11-10) and may change to match changes to requirements specifications (implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-5; OG [9, 10])

Name: All Combinations Testing
Definition: Testing that "focuses on all … the possible input combinations" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Parent(s): Combinatorial Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)

Name: All-C-Uses Testing
Definition: Testing that aims to execute all "use[s] of the value of a variable in any type of statement" (IEEE, 2017, p. 83; OG IEEE, 2015) as "defined in [a given] data definition"? (IEEE, 2017, p. 115; OG IEEE, 2015)
Parent(s): Data Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Synonym(s): All Computation Data Uses (implied by IEEE, 2017, p. 83)
Notes: See also van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: All-Definitions Testing
Definition: Testing that aims to execute all "statement[s] where a variable is assigned a value"? (IEEE, 2017, p. 115; OG IEEE, 2015)
Parent(s): Data Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: A "weaker strateg[y]" than all-DU-paths testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13). See also van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: All-DU-Paths Testing
Definition: Testing that "requires executing, for each variable, every control flow path segment from a definition of that variable to the use of that definition" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), or that aims to execute all "predicate or computational data use[s that] … use[] the value defined in [a given] data definition"? (IEEE, 2017, p. 125; OG IEEE, 2015)
Parent(s): Data Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: "The strongest data flow testing criterion" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13). See also van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: All-P-Uses Testing
Definition: Testing that aims to execute all "predicate data use[s that] … use[] the value defined in [a given] data definition"? (IEEE, 2017, p. 115; OG IEEE, 2015)
Parent(s): Data Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: See also van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: All-Uses Testing
Parent(s): Data Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: A "weaker strateg[y]" than all-DU-paths testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13). See also van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: Alpha Testing
Approach Category: Level (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; inferred from acceptance testing)
Definition: The "first stage of testing before a product is considered ready for commercial or operational use" (IEEE, 2017, p. 17)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Dennis et al., 2012, p. 455); Unscripted Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Notes: "Often performed only by users within the organization developing the software" (IEEE, 2017, p. 17), by "a small, selected group of potential users" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8), or "in the developer's test environment by roles outside the development organization" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). Related to beta testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 17; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)

Name: API Testing
Definition: A specific form of interface testing that "simulate[s] the use of APIs by end-user applications", including "generating parameters", "defining internal data" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10), and "submitting requests" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Interface Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)

Name: Application System Testing
Parent(s): Functionality Testing, System Testing, Functional Testing, Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)

Name: Architecture-driven Testing
Definition: Testing that "verifies" the "system conforms to [the specified] architecture" (Firesmith, 2015, p. 33)

Name: At-the-End Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29)
Definition: Testing that occurs as "the last phase of the development life cycle" (Gerrard, 2000, p. 8)
Parent(s): Waterfall Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29)
Notes: "The most costly and least effective way of performing testing" (Gerrard, 2000, p. 8)

Name: Attacks
Definition: Testing with the goal of "exploiting a specific … way of thinking about how and why software fails … [which] can be behaviour-based" (IEEE, 2022, p. 34), including by "attempting to trigger specific failures" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Experience-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 34)
Notes: This term can also be defined as a "malicious action or interaction with the system or its environment that has the potential to result in a fault or an error, and thereby possibly in a failure, or an adverse consequence" (IEEE, 2019, p. 7) which is essentially the same definition with the modification of being "malicious"; like the difference between white- and black-hat hacking

Name: Audio Testing
Definition: "Testing to determine if the game music and sound effects will engage the user in the game and enhance the game play [sic]" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Audits
Definition: "Independent examination[s] of … work products to assess compliance with specifications, standards, contractual agreements, or other criteria" (IEEE, 2017, p. 36; OG ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016) "often mandated to be performed by third parties" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-14; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Static Analysis? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-13), Static Testing, Compliance Testing (implied by IEEE, 2022, p. 44)
Notes: Also described as testing "used to verify compliance with standards" (IEEE, 2022, p. 44)

Name: Availability Testing
Approach Category: Type (implied by its quality (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, p. 38; OG ISO/IEC 16350-2015))
Definition: Testing the "capability of a product to be operational and accessible when required for use" (ISO/IEC, 2023a) or "to perform its required function at an agreed instant or over an agreed period of time" (IEEE, 2017, p. 38; OG ISO/IEC 16350-2015), usually represented as a ratio, percentage (IEEE, 2017, p. 38), or proportion (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Parent(s): Reliability Testing (ISO/IEC, 2023a; Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-10), Security Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 404), Dependability Testing (if it exists) (ISO/IEC, 2023a), Non-functional Testing, Automated Testing, Dynamic Testing, Post-Deployment Monitoring (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)
Notes: Can be supported by "failover or duplication of systems" (ISO/IEC, 2023a). Related to robustness testing, as well as error/fault tolerance testing (if they exist) (IEEE, 2017, p. 38)

Name: Automated Testing
Definition: Testing "executed by a test automation tool" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35) such as test drivers (Gerrard, 2000, p. 11)
Parent(s): Scripted Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 33), Development Testing (can be) (Gerrard, 2000, p. 11)
Notes: Often cost-effective "if a set of test cases is going to be executed 5 or more times" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35) but "must be automated as much as possible throughout the entire software delivery process, including throughout development and operations", and at all levels (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-13); it is time-consuming to "automate manual tests later" (Gerrard, 2000, p. 11). See also "automated verification system " (IEEE, 2017, p. 37)

Name: Back-to-Back Testing
Definition: Testing "whereby an alternative version of the system is used to generate expected results for comparison from the same test inputs" (IEEE, 2022, p.2) or where "two or more variants of a program are executed with the same inputs, the outputs are compared, and errors are analyzed in case of discrepancies" (IEEE, 2017, p. 38; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; OG Spillner)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)
Notes: "Not a test case generation technique as test inputs are not generated" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35). Similar to testing using a pseudo-oracle (Barr et al., 2015, p. 515) and related to mutation testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 38)

Name: Backup and Recovery Testing
Definition: Testing "that measures the degree to which system state can be restored from backup within specified parameters of time, cost, completeness, and accuracy in the event of failure" (IEEE, 2013, p. 2)
Parent(s): Reliability Testing (IEEE, 2013, p. 2)
Notes: Nonatomic; captures both "backup" and "recovery". Seems to be what is meant by "recovery testing" in the context of performance

Name: Backup Testing (implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-8)
Notes: "Should be constantly rehearsed as changes to the production environment are made" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-8)

Name: Base Choice Testing
Parent(s): Combinatorial Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)

Name: Beta Testing
Definition: The "second stage of testing when a product is in limited production use" (IEEE, 2017, p. 17)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Dennis et al., 2012, p. 455); Unscripted Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8, implied by Dennis et al., 2012, p. 455)
Notes: "Often performed at a customer site" (IEEE, 2017, p. 45) by "a larger set of representative users" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8) or, more specifically, "at an external site to the developer's test environment by roles outside the development organization" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024); related to alpha testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)

Name: Big-Bang Testing
Definition: "Testing in which … [components of a system] are combined all at once into an overall system, rather than in stages" (IEEE, 2017, p. 45)
Parent(s): Integration Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7; IEEE, 2017, p. 45)

Name: Bottom-Up Testing
Definition: Integration testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7) that "starts with the lowest‐level components … and proceeds through progressively higher‐levels" (IEEE, 2017, p. 49; OG ISO/IEC 2015)
Parent(s): Integration Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7)
Notes: Difference between this as integration testing vs. not (as in Firesmith, 2015, p. 28)?

Name: Boundary Value Analysis
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 2, 20, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing "based on exercising the boundaries of equivalence partitions" (IEEE, 2022, p. 2; simlar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024) (i.e., "minimum or maximum input[s], internal [values], or output value[s] specified for a system or component" (IEEE, 2017, p. 49))
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 2, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Equivalence Partitioning (IEEE, 2022, p. 2; implied by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5), Functional Testing? (IEEE, 2022, p. 20)
Notes: Seems to be related to stress testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 49); See also Patton, 2006, pp. 70-74

Name: Branch Condition Combination Testing
Definition: Testing "designed to exercise outcome combinations of atomic conditions" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Synonym(s): (Multiple) Condition Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Patton, 2006, p. 120), Condition Combination Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Extended Branch Coverage? (van Vliet, 2000, p. 422)
Notes: Difference between this and branch condition testing?

Name: Branch Condition Testing
Parent(s): Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Synonym(s): (Multiple) Condition Testing? (Patton, 2006, p. 120), Extended Branch Coverage? (van Vliet, 2000, p. 422)
Notes: Difference between this and branch condition combination testing?

Name: Branch Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 2, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing "based on exercising branches [or "execut[ing] each outcome of each decision point" (IEEE, 2017, p. 51)] in the control flow of the test item" (IEEE, 2022, p. 2)
Parent(s): Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 2, 22; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: IEEE (2017, p. 51) says it is "designed to execute each outcome of each decision point"; is this level of coverage required or advised?

Name: Browser Page Testing
Parent(s): Smoke Testing, Functional Testing, Dynamic Testing, Desktop Development Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)

Name: Browser Syntax Compatibility (Testing?)
Parent(s): Smoke Testing, Automated Testing, Static Testing, Desktop Development Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)

Name: Buddy Testing
Definition: Testing that "generates test cases by using internal architecture knowledge and testing specific knowledge" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14); this definition seems vague
Parent(s): Ad Hoc Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Notes: Related to pair testing?

Name: Build Verification Testing (BVT)
Definition: "Automated test[ing] that validates the integrity of each new build and verifies its key/core functionality, stability, and testability" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Automated Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024); Integrity, Functionality, Stability, and Testability Testing (if they exist)

Name: Business Acceptance Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)
Approach Category: Level (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from acceptance testing)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Business Process Testing
Definition: Scenario-based testing focused "on the roles in a workflow specification" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Parent(s): Scenario-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)

Name: Canary (Release) Testing (see Washizaki, 2024, pp. 6-5, 6-10)
Definition: "A partial and time-limited deployment of a change in a service and an evaluation of that change" to help "decide whether to proceed with a complete deployment" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-10)
Notes: A method for "testing the software in the production system context" which "can be particularly challenging" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5)

Name: Capacity Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; 2013, p. 2; implied by its quality (ISO/IEC, 2023a))
Definition: Testing that evaluates the "capability of a product to meet requirements for the maximum limits of a product parameter", such as the number of concurrent users, transaction throughput, or database size (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Parent(s): Performance Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Performance Efficiency Testing (IEEE, 2013, p. 2; ISO/IEC, 2023a), Volume Testing (potentially) (IEEE, 2017, p. 508; OG 2013)
Notes: Has the following subcategories from IEEE (2017): channel capacity (p. 67), memory capacity (p. 270), storage capacity (p. 441)

Name: Capture-Replay Driven Testing
Approach Category: Practice (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; inferred from automated testing); Approach (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: "A test automation approach in which inputs to the test object are recorded during manual testing to generate automated test scripts that can be executed later" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Automated Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 22, 35; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Cause-Effect Graphing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising decision rules in a cause-effect graph" (IEEE, 2022, p. 2)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)
Notes: Related to decision table testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)

Name: Certification
Definition: The "process of confirming that a system or component complies with its specified requirements and is acceptable for operational use" (IEEE, 2017, p. 63; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024); usually done by a third-party (IEEE, 2017, p. 63; OG ISO/IEC 2015)

Name: Change-Related Testing
Definition: "Testing initiated by modification to a component or system" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Checklist-based Reviews
Definition: "Review[s] … guided by a list of questions or required attributes" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Checklist-based Testing, Reviews
Notes: See ISO 20246

Name: Checklist-based Testing
Definition: Testing generated "based on a list of pre-determined items" that "can be based on personal experience, commonly found defects, and perceived risks" (IEEE, 2022, p. 34)
Parent(s): Experience-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 34; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: "Often focused on a particular quality characteristic" (IEEE, 2022, p. 34). See also Patton, 2006, pp. 61, 99-103

Name: Classification Tree Method
Definition: Testing "designed using a classification tree" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; OG Grochtmann)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Related to combinatorial testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Code Injection
Definition: "A type of security attack performed by inserting malicious code at an interface into an application to exploit poor handling of untrusted data" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Security Attacks (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Interface Testing (implied by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Code Reviews
Definition: A "meeting at which software code is presented to project personnel, managers, users, customers, or other interested parties for comment or approval" (IEEE, 2017, p. 74); can also be done "using a pull request technique/tool … before [the code] can be merged into [the] project" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-13)
Parent(s): Reviews (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-13), Peer Reviews (sometimes) (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-13), Static Analysis? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-13)
Notes: Sometimes kept separate from testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-11). Seems to line up most closely with the notion of "peer review" from Patton (2006, p. 94) and van Vliet (2000, p. 414)

Name: Co-existence Testing (sometimes without hyphen; see Hamburg and Mogyorodi (2024))
Approach Category: Type (inferred from compatibility and interoperability testing and implied by its quality (ISO/IEC, 2023a))
Definition: "Testing that measures the degree to which a test item can function satisfactorily alongside other independent products in a shared environment" (IEEE, 2022, p. 3; similar in ISO/IEC, 2023a) "without a negative impact on any of them" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; similar in ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Parent(s): Compatibility Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 3; ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: Testing approach not mentioned explicitly by IEEE (2022), Hamburg and Mogyorodi (2024), or ISO/IEC (2023a). Related to portability testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Combinatorial Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 3, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing that "systematically derive[s] … test cases that cover specific parameters of values or conditions" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11) by choosing "specific combinations of values" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 3, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Synonym(s): Combinatorial Test Design Techniques (IEEE, 2022, p. 3) (a little redundant)
Notes: Related to the classification tree method (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). See also Engström and Petersen, 2015

Name: Compatibility Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, pp. 3, 22; 2013, p. 2; implied by its quality (ISO/IEC, 2023a))
Definition: "Testing that measures the degree to which a test item can function satisfactorily alongside other independent products in a shared environment (co-existence), and where necessary, exchanges information with other systems or components (interoperability)" (IEEE, 2022, p. 3; 2013, p. 2; similar in ISO/IEC, 2023a and Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)
Notes: Not atomic and implies the existence of "co-existence testing" and "interoperability testing", which is made more explicit by ISO/IEC (2023a). Includes both "different hardware and software facilities" and "different versions or releases" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9). Likely has two subtypes: "downward compatibility testing" (implied by IEEE, 2017, p. 147) and "upward compatibility testing" (implied by IEEE, 2017, p. 492)

Name: Compliance Testing
Approach Category: Type (implied by its quality (IEEE, 2017, p. 82; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024))
Definition: Testing that "validates" (Firesmith, 2015, p. 33) the "adherance of [the test item] … to standards, conventions or regulations in laws and similar prescriptions" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; OG IREB Glossary; similar in Firesmith, 2015, p. 33) usually "forced by an external regulatory body" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Notes: "Audits are often used to verify compliance with standards" (IEEE, 2022, p. 44)

Name: Component Integration Testing
Approach Category: Level (IEEE, 2017, p. 467; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; inferred from integration testing)
Definition: "Testing of groups of related components" (IEEE, 2017, p. 82) or "integration testing of components" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Integration Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Synonym(s): Module Integration Testing, Unit Integration Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Difference between this, integration testing, and unit testing?

Name: Command-Line Interface (CLI) Testing
Definition: "Testing performed by submitting commands to the software under test using a dedicated command-line interface" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Concurrency Testing
Definition: "Testing to evaluate if a component or system involving concurrency behaves as specified" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Condition Testing
Definition: Testing "in which test conditions are outcomes of atomic conditions" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Structure-based Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024); Decision Testing?
Notes: Hamburg and Mogyorodi (2024) make the distinction that this only involves atomic conditions, but Washizaki (2024, p. 5-13) doesn't, considering these two terms to be synonyms

Name: Configuration Testing
Definition: Testing that "verifies the software under specified configurations" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10), or "arrangement[s] … defined by … its constituent parts[,] … requirements, design, and[/or] implementation" (IEEE, 2017, p. 90), when it "is built to serve different users" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)
Parent(s): Smoke Testing, Non-functional Testing, Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2), Data Center Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 24), Development Testing (can be) (Gerrard, 2000, p. 11)
Notes: Can be done by an audit (IEEE, 2017, p. 90)

Name: Construction Testing
Definition: Testing that "aims to reduce the gap between when faults are inserted into the code and when those faults are detected, thereby reducing the cost incurred to fix them" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 4-7)
Notes: "Involves two forms of testing, which are often performed by the software engineer who wrote the code: unit testing and integration testing", but not "more specialized testing" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 4-7). IEEE (2017, p. 95) defines a process just called "construction" that includes unit testing (but not integration testing). See also IEEE Standard 829-1998 and IEEE Standard 1008-1987

Name: Content Checking
Parent(s): Usability Testing, Static Testing, Desktop Development Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)

Name: Continuous Testing
Approach Category: Practice (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-13); Approach (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024); Process?
Definition: Testing "started via an automated process that can occur on-demand" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35) "that involves testing the software at every stage of the software development life cycle" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-13) "to obtain feedback … as rapidly as possible" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Automated Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 35; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Lifecycle-based Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29), Development Testing (can be) (Gerrard, 2000, p. 11)
Notes: Involves testing early (IEEE, 2022, p. 35; Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), often (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), and everywhere (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), and ideally employs "prioritization", the process of "defin[ing] a test execution order according to some criteria" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-4), so that time isn't wasted on lower priority tests

Name: Contractual Acceptance Testing
Approach Category: Level (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from acceptance testing)
Definition: "Acceptance testing performed to verify whether a system satisfies its contractual requirements" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)
Synonym(s): Contract Acceptance Testing, CAT (conflicts with "customer AT") (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Control Flow Analysis
Definition: "Analysis based on a representation of unique paths for executing a component or system" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Static Analysis (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Control Flow Testing
Definition: Testing that "covers all" of a particular subdivision of code (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), namely the "sequence in which operations are performed during … execution" (IEEE, 2017, p. 101; OG IEEE, 2015)
Parent(s): Structure-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Notes: "The adequacy of such tests is measured in percentages" and can also be performed on "blocks of statements[] or specific combinations of statements" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13); would these be a different testing type? Related to data flow testing? (IEEE, 2017, p. 101)

Name: Conversion Testing
Definition: Testing that verifies that the software can be modified "to enable it to operate with similar functional capability in a different environment" (IEEE, 2017, p. 103)
Parent(s): Portability Testing?

Name: CGI Component Testing
Parent(s): Smoke Testing, Infrastructure Testing, Functional Testing, Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2), Unit Testing
Synonym(s): Common Gateway Interface Component Testing (Gerrard, 2000, p. 17)

Name: Crowd Testing
Definition: Testing performed by "a large group of testers" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Customer Acceptance Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)
Approach Category: Level (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from acceptance testing)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Dark Launches
Notes: A method for "testing the software in the production system context" which "can be particularly challenging" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5)

Name: Data Center Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 24)
Parent(s): Operational Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Data Flow Analysis
Definition: "Analysis based on the lifecycle of variables" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Static Analysis (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Data Flow Testing
Definition: Control flow testing with additional "information about how the variables are defined, used, and killed" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Parent(s): Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Control Flow Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Notes: May involve data flow analysis or "data analysis". Related to control flow testing? (IEEE, 2017, p. 101). See also IEEE (2017, p. 166), Patton (2006, p. 114) and van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: Data-driven Testing
Definition: Testing "that uses data files to contain the test data and expected results needed to execute the test scripts" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Automated Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 22, 35; implied by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Similar to keyword-driven testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Decision Table Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 4, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing "based on exercising decision rules in a decision table" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024) "by considering every possible combination of conditions and their corresponding resultant actions" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 4, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Model-based Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-10)
Notes: Related to cause-effect graphing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11). See also Peters and Pedrycz (2000, pp. 448, 450-453)

Name: Decision Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 4, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing "based on exercising decision outcomes in the control flow of the test item" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 4, 22; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Defect-based Testing
Definition: Testing "in which test cases are developed from what is known about a specific defect type" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Fault-Based Testing?
Notes: Related to the idea of a "defect taxonomy" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Denial of Service
Definition: "Security attack[s] … intended to overload the system with requests such that legitimate requests cannot be serviced" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Security Attacks (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Stress Testing?

Name: Design-driven Testing
Definition: Testing that "verifies" the "system conforms to [the specified] design" (Firesmith, 2015, p. 33)

Name: Desk Checking
Definition: A "manual simulation of program execution" or visual examination of code listings, test results, or other documentation to "detect faults" and " identify errors" (IEEE, 2017, p. 133; OG ISO/IEC 2015)
Notes: Related to inspections and walkthroughs (IEEE, 2017, p. 133)

Name: Desktop Development Testing
Definition: Testing of web-based applications that focuses on, "broadly, what the browser executes" (Gerrard, 2000, p. 13)

Name: Deterministic Testing?
Notes: In contrast to random testing; it is unclear if this is an actual test approach or simply a method for selecting input data, etc. for tests (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-16)

Name: Development Environment Testing
Parent(s): Development Testing?

Name: Development Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted during the development of a system or component, usually in the development environment by the developer … to establish whether … [it] satisfies its criteria" (IEEE, 2017, p. 136)
Synonym(s): Developer Testing? (Gerrard, 2000, p. 11), Developmental Testing (DT)? (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)
Notes: The secondary definition, "testing conducted to establish whether a new software product or software‐based system (or components of it) satisfies its criteria" (IEEE, 2017, p. 136), seems to overlap with acceptance testing. Can be used to generate test cases for regression testing (Gerrard, 2000, p. 11); is this sufficient for a "parent" relation? There are "[m]any [t]ypes" (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30), but no examples are given

Name: Development Tool Testing
Parent(s): Development Testing?

Name: Dev/Sec/Ops Testing? (implied by Dev/Sec/Ops (Washizaki, 2024, p. 9-5) and DevOps testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29))
Definition: DevOps testing that "applies security at all phases of the software life cycle", including in the testing phase (Washizaki, 2024, p. 9-5)
Parent(s): DevOps Testing, Security Testing, Agile Testing, Shift-Left Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 9-5), Continuous Testing, Automated Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 9-5; implied by DevOps testing)

Name: DevOps Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29)
Definition: Testing performed in the context of DevOps: a "set of principles and practices … for … specifying, developing, and operating software and systems products and services, and continuous improvements in all aspects of the life cycle" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-7; OG [11])
Parent(s): Continuous Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29; implied by Washizaki, 2024, pp. 10-7 (OG [11]), 11-11), Automated Testing (implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 11-11)

Name: Device-based Testing
Definition: "Testing in which test suites are executed on physical or virtual devices" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Disaster/Recovery Testing (or Disaster Recovery Testing (implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-8; IEEE, 2013, p. 20))
Definition: Testing to determine the degree to which a system can "return to normal operation after a hardware or software failure " (IEEE, 2017, p. 140)
Notes: "Requires stopping the service, identifying the checkpoint state and triggering the failover process"; "should be constantly rehearsed as changes to the production environment are made" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-8). Difference between this and recovery testing (in the context of performance)?

Name: Domain-Independent Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 26)
Parent(s): Domain-Based Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 26)
Notes: There are "[m]any [t]ypes" (Firesmith, 2015, p. 26), but no examples are given

Name: Domain-Specific Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 26)
Parent(s): Domain-Based Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 26)
Notes: All examples given by Firesmith (2015, p. 26) are focused on hardware, but this might not be representative

Name: Dynamic Analysis
Definition: The "process of evaluating a system or component based on its behavior during execution" (IEEE, 2017, p. 149)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing? (implied by their static counterparts in IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 17, 25, 28 and Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: This definition seems vague, but may have a similar relation to "dynamic testing" as between the static counterparts

Name: Dynamic Testing
Definition: "Testing in which a test item is evaluated by executing it" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4)
Notes: Can "only occur in the parts of the life cycle when executable code is available" (IEEE, 2022, p. 18)

Name: Each Choice Testing
Parent(s): Combinatorial Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)

Name: Elasticity Testing
Definition: Testing that "assesses the ability of the SUT … to rapidly expand or shrink compute, memory, and storage resources without compromising the capacity to meet peak utilization" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)
Notes: Some objectives are "to control behaviors, to identify the resources to be (un)allocated, to coordinate events in parallel, and to evaluate scalability" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9); the last one seems like it should be under scalability testing?

Name: End-to-end Functionality Testing
Parent(s): Smoke Testing, Dynamic Testing, Systems Integration Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2), Functionality Testing, End-to-end Testing
Synonym(s): Spelled without hyphens by Gerrard (2000, Tab. 2), but they were added for consistency

Name: End-to-end Testing
Definition: Testing "in which business processes are tested from start to finish under production-like circumstances" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Operational (Acceptance) Testing?
Notes: Ambiguous: does this test the business processes or the system?

Name: Endurance Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted to evaluate whether a test item can sustain a required load ["significant" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)] continuously for a specified period of time" (IEEE, 2013, p. 2; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024) "within the system's operational context" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Performance Efficiency Testing (IEEE, 2013, p. 2)

Name: Equivalence Partitioning
Definition: Testing "designed to exercise equivalence partitions by using one or more representative members of each partition" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4; 2013, p. 3) "based on a specified criterion or relation" to create "a representative test suite" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5), Functional Testing? (IEEE, 2022, p. 20)
Synonym(s): Equivalence Classing (although this sometimes has a bit different of a definition; see IEEE, 2017, p. 164) (Patton, 2006, p. 67; implied by IEEE, 2022, p. 4), Partition Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Ergonomics Testing
Definition: "Testing to determine whether a component or system and its input devices are being used properly with correct posture" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Does this test the system or its use?

Name: Error Guessing
Definition: Testing based on "the tester's knowledge of past failures, or general knowledge of failure modes" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4; 2013, p. 3) "to anticipate the most plausible faults in each SUT" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Parent(s): Experience-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 4, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Fault-based Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-9)
Notes: See Patton (2006, pp. 88-89)

Name: Error Seeding
Definition: The "process of intentionally adding known faults to those already in a computer program … [to] estimat[e] the number of faults remaining" (IEEE, 2017, p. 165)
Synonym(s): Fault Seeding (IEEE, 2017, p. 165; van Vliet, 2000, p. 427), Bug Seeding (IEEE, 2017, p. 165), Bebugging (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: See van Vliet (2000, pp. 427-428)

Name: Evidence-based Testing
Definition: Testing that "follows a rigorous research approach", including "identifying" and "critically analyzing the evidence in light of the problem" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Notes: "Evidence-based software engineering (EBSE) … is the _best_ solution for a practical problem" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12); related to experience-based testing?

Name: Exhaustive Testing
Definition: Testing "in which all combinations of input values and preconditions are tested" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4; similar to Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 18)
Notes: Impossible in most non-trivial situations (IEEE, 2022, p. 4; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-5; van Vliet, 2000, p. 421; Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, pp. 439, 461)

Name: Experience-based Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 4, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Practice (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Definition: Testing based on testers' experience (IEEE, 2022, p. 4; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), knowledge, and intuition (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), as well as the SUT's context (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 17), Unscripted Testing (often) (IEEE, 2022, p. 34)
Notes: "Can include concepts such as test attacks, tours, and error taxonomies" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4). See Patton (2006, pp. 88-89)

Name: Expert Usability Reviews
Definition: "Informal usability review[s] in which the reviewers are … usability experts [and/]or subject matter experts" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Informal Testing, Usability Testing, Reviews (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Exploratory Testing
Approach Category: Technique (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14; inferred from experience-based testing), Practice (IEEE, 2022, pp. 20, 22, 34)
Definition: "Simultaneous learning, test design and test execution" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024) that is "spontaneous" and aims to find "hidden properties" that "can interfere with other properties of the software under test" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5; 2013, p. 3)
Parent(s): Experience-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 5; 2013, p. 3; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14); Unscripted Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 33; 2017, p. 174; implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Notes: "Test cases are not defined in advance but are dynamically designed, executed, and modified according to the collected evidence" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), but this process is often structured with "session sheets", which are also "used to capture information about what was tested, and any anomalous behaviour observed" (2022, p. 33), or "test charters" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). Patton says this is used when a specification is not available to determine and test the software's features (2006, p. 65). "Widely used in shift-left development (such as Agile)" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14). See Whittaker (2010)

Name: Extended Entry Table Testing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising decision rules" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4) in an extended entry table (IEEE, 2017, p. 175; OG ISO, 1984)
Parent(s): Decision Table Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 175; OG ISO, 1984)

Name: External Links Integration (Testing) (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)
Parent(s): Functional Testing, Dynamic Testing, Large Scale Integration (Testing) (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2), Integration Testing

Name: Factory Acceptance Testing
Approach Category: Level (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from acceptance testing)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Failover Testing
Definition: Testing that "validates the SUT’s ability to manage heavy loads or unexpected failure to continue typical operations" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9) by entering a "backup operational mode in which [these responsibilities] … are assumed by a secondary system" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), Data Center Testing? (Firestorm, 2015, p. 24)
Notes: Can be done by "allocating extra resources" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9) and "should be constantly rehearsed as changes to the production environment are made" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-8). Related to recoverability validation (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)

Name: Fault Injection Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 42)
Definition: Testing where "faults are artificially introduced into the SUT" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-18) to, at least partially, "test the robustness of the system in the event of internal and external failures" (IEEE, 2022, p. 42) and "whether it can detect and possibly recover from [them]" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Robustness Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 42)

Name: Fault Tree Analysis
Definition: "A technique for analyzing the causes of failures that uses a hierarchical model of events and their logical relationships" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Static Analysis

Name: Fault-Based Testing
Definition: Testing that "devise[s] test cases specifically to reveal likely or predefined fault categories" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)

Name: Feature-based Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 28)
Parent(s): Unit Testing? (implied by Firesmith, 2015, p. 28)

Name: Features Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5), Integration Testing? (implied by Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)

Name: Field Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted to evaluate the system behavior under productive connectivity conditions in the field" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Operational (Acceptance) Testing?

Name: Follow-on Operational Testing
Parent(s): Operational Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Forcing Exception Testing
Definition: Testing that "check[s] whether the SUT can manage a predefined set of exceptions/errors" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Parent(s): Scenario-based Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Notes: Related to the "test-to-fail" approach (Patton, 2006, pp. 66-67)

Name: Formal Reviews
Definition: "Review[s] that follow[] … defined process[es] with … formally documented output[s]" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Reviews (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-14; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Formal Testing
Notes: See ISO 20246

Name: Formal Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted in accordance with test plans and procedures that have been reviewed and approved" (IEEE, 2017, p. 188)
Notes: Since informal testing still follows "test plans and procedures" (IEEE, 2017, p. 220), this is probably not related to scripted testing (at least specifically)

Name: Formative Evaluations
Definition: "Evaluation[s] designed and used to improve the quality of a component or system, especially when it is still being designed" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Development Testing?

Name: Functional Suitability Testing (mentioned by IEEE (2022, p. 7); implied by its quality (ISO/IEC, 2023a))
Definition: Testing to determine the "capability of a product to provide functions that meet stated and implied needs of intended users when it is used under specified conditions" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Synonym(s): Functionality Testing? (implied by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: This includes meeting "the functional specification" (ISO/IEC, 2023a), but originally explicitly didn't (2011). Difference between this and functional testing?

Name: Functional Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, pp. 15, 20, 22; implied by the quality of "correctness" (IEEE, 2017, p. 104; Washizaki, 2024, p. 3-13))
Definition: Testing "used to check the implementation of functional requirements" (IEEE, 2022, p. 21), which "identif[y] what results a product or process shall produce" (IEEE, 2017, p. 195) based on software algorithms that support work tasks (p. 422), and "to verify that the SUT conforms to standards, rules, specifications, requirements, design, processes, or practices" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7)
Parent(s): Functional Suitability Testing?

Name: Functional Testing
Definition: "Testing that … focuses solely on the outputs generated in response to selected inputs and execution conditions" or that "evaluate[s] the compliance of a system or component with specified functional requirements" (IEEE, 2017, p. 196) which "identif[y] what results" (IEEE, 2017, p. 195) or "observable behaviours that the software is to provide (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-4)
Parent(s): Automated Testing (can be) (Gerrard, 2000, p. 11)
Synonym(s): Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 196; van Vliet, 2000, p. 399)
Notes: Difference between this and specification-based testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 196; van Vliet, 2000, p. 399; Souza et al., 2017, p. 3)?

Name: Functionality Testing
Definition: Testing of the "capabilities of the various … features provided by a product" (IEEE, 2017, p. 196)
Parent(s): Build Verification Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Functionality Suitability Testing?
Synonym(s): Functional Suitability Testing? (seems incorrect) (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Should be performed "in all projects", possibly implicitly "during development and user evaluation", but is "typically the … most expensive and time consuming to implement and execute" (Gerrard, 2000, p. 13). Difference between this and functional testing? Gerrard makes a distinction between them (2000, Tab. 2)

Name: Fuzz Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, p. 36; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Practice? (inferred from mathematical-based testing)
Definition: Testing where "high volumes of random (or near random) data, called fuzz, are used to generate [test] inputs" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024) "aimed at breaking the software" (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-8) or "discover[ing] security vulnerabilities" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Mathematical-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 36), Security Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Random Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-8; implied by IEEE, 2022, p. 5; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Often used for security testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-8). This is tagged (?) as "artificial intelligence" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5), but I don't think AI is required

Name: Gray-Box Testing
Approach Category: Technique (implied by its white- and black- counterparts)
Definition: Black-box testing that is "supplement[ed] … by taking a peek (not a full look, as in white-box testing) at what makes the software work" (Patton, 2006, p. 218)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Patton, 2006, p. 218)

Name: GUI Testing
Definition: "Testing performed by interacting with the software under test via the graphical user interface" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing

Name: Heuristic Evaluation
Definition: "Usability review[s] … that evaluate[] a work product by using a set of heuristics" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Usability Reviews (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Usability Testing (Gerrard, 2000, p. 13)

Name: High-Level Testing
Definition: Testing "with concrete values for preconditions, input data, expected results, postconditions, and a detailed description of actions (where applicable)" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: OG definition was about test cases, not a test approach

Name: HTML Testing
Parent(s): Smoke Testing, Static Testing, Desktop Development Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2), Gray-Box Testing? (Patton, 2006, p. 220)
Notes: This may include looking at HTML code and checking the tags used as described by Patton (2006, p. 220)

Name: Human-in-the-Loop Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)
Parent(s): System Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)

Name: Hypothesis Testing
Definition: "Validation of a theory and its assumptions using sample data" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Ambiguous: what is a "theory"? why use "sample data" and not just "data"? is it specific to software or does it just refer to general science? Potentially related to model verification

Name: Incremental Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29)
Definition: Testing that "occur[s] in an overlapping … manner" to other phases of development (IEEE, 2017, p. 218) "through a series of iterations" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-5; OG [3, 8, 13])
Parent(s): Lifecycle-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-5; OG [2, 3, 10]; Firesmith, 2015, p. 29)

Name: Informal Reviews
Definition: "Review[s] that do[] not follow a defined process and ha[ve] no formally documented output" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Reviews (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-14; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Informal Testing

Name: Informal Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted in accordance with test plans and procedures that have not been reviewed and approved by a customer, user, or designated level of management" (IEEE, 2017, p. 220)

Name: Infrastructure Testing
Definition: Testing of "infrastructure components[, or "what runs on the servers" (Gerrard, 2000, p. 13),] to reduce the chances of downtime and improve the performance of the IT infrastructure" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)

Name: Initial Operational Testing
Parent(s): Operational Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Input Data Testing
Definition: Testing "that focuses on the quality of the data used for training and prediction by ML models" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): ML Model Testing

Name: Input Validation Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)

Name: Insourced Testing
Definition: "Testing performed by people who are co-located with the project team but are not fellow employees" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: (Code) Inspections
Definition: "Visual examination[s] of … [code] to detect and identify software anomalies, including errors and deviations from standards and specifications" (IEEE, 2017, p. 227; OG IEEE, 2008) that are "led by impartial facilitators who are trained in inspection techniques" (IEEE, 2017, p. 227) and "use[] defined team roles and measurement" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Static Analysis (IEEE, 2017, p. 227), Static Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 227; Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 4, p. 12), Formal Reviews (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Related to peer reviews (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). Could also include inspection of the software product itself, like in the context of usability (Gerrard, 2000, p. 13)? See ISO 20246

Name: Installability Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; 2017, p. 228; implied by its quality)
Definition: "Testing conducted to evaluate whether … test items can be installed [and/or uninstalled (ISO/IEC, 2023a)] as required in all specified environments" (IEEE, 2017, p. 228; OG IEEE, 2013) or a specific one (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Parent(s): Portability Testing (ISO/IEC, 2023a; IEEE, 2017, p. 228); Replaceability Testing? (ISO/IEC, 2023a)

Name: Installation Testing
Approach Category: Level (Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, p. 445; implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Definition: "System testing conducted in the operational environment of hardware configurations and other operational constraints"; may also verify installation procedures (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5), System Testing? (implied by Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5), Online Testing?
Notes: "Typically observe[s] the newly started server for a while, ensuring that the server doesn’t crash or otherwise misbehave" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-10)

Name: Integrated System Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 24)
Parent(s): Data Center Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 24)

Name: Integration Testing
Approach Category: Level (IEEE, 2022, pp. 12, 20-22, 26-27; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing that "verifies the interactions among SUT elements (for instance, components, modules, or subsystems)" as well as "external interfaces" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7) in a "progressive" manner (IEEE, 2017, p. 231)
Parent(s): Construction Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 4-7)
Notes: More effective when automated (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-14) and "can be performed at each development stage" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7). IEEE (2017, p. 231) says it can be used when integrating systems; is this captured by "subsystems" in the SWEBOK definition? See also (Patton, 2006, p. 109)

Name: Interface Testing
Approach Category: Level (implied by IEEE, 2017, p. 235 and integration testing)
Definition: Testing that "aims to verify whether the components' interface provides the correct exchange of data and control information" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; similar in IEEE, 2017, p. 235)
Parent(s): Integration Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: "Usually, the test cases are generated from the interface specification" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)

Name: Internationalization (Testing)
Parent(s): Usability Testing, Functional Testing, Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)

Name: Interoperability Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; implied by its quality (ISO/IEC, 2023a))
Definition: Testing that aims to evaluate the "capability of a product to exchange information with other products [or "systems of different types" (IEEE, 2017, p. 238)] and mutually use the information that has been exchanged" (ISO/IEC, 2023a) or that "a modified system retains [this] capability" (IEEE, 2017, p. 238)
Parent(s): Compatibility Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 3; ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: Originally defined in the context of "two or more systems, products or components" (ISO/IEC, 2011). See "passive interconnection" (IEEE, 2017, p. 315; OG IEEE, 2006) potentially?

Name: Keyword-driven Testing
Definition: Testing that uses "test scripts … [with] high-level keywords and supporting files that contain low-level scripts that implement those keywords" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Scripted Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Automated Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 35)
Notes: Similar to data-driven testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). See also ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-5

Name: Layer-based Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 28)
Parent(s): Unit Testing? (implied by Firesmith, 2015, p. 28)

Name: Legacy System Integration (Testing) (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)
Parent(s): Functional Testing, Dynamic Testing, Large Scale Integration (Testing) (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2), System Integration Testing

Name: License Compliance Audits
Definition: "Audit[s] that reconcile[] license‐related information from multiple information sources, such as entitlement consumption against entitlement rights" (IEEE, 2017, p. 250)
Parent(s): Audits (IEEE, 2017, p. 250)

Name: Lifecycle-based Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29)
Notes: "Generally speaking, [the production stage of an SLCP] will include the production and testing of the system" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-7)

Name: Linear Scripting
Definition: Scripted testing "without any control structure in the test scripts" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Scripted Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Link Checking
Parent(s): Smoke Testing, Test Browsing, Automated Testing, Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)

Name: Load Balancing Testing (implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5)
Notes: May be done by "us[ing] infrastructure/operations services" early on in the development process (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5)

Name: Load Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, pp. 5, 20, 22; 2017, p. 253; OG IEEE 2013; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing "conducted to evaluate the behaviour of a test item under anticipated conditions of varying load" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5; 2017, p. 253; OG IEEE 2013; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9); Performance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 5; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Performance Efficiency Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 253; OG IEEE 2013)
Notes: Loads used are "usually between anticipated conditions of low, typical, and peak usage" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5; 2017, p. 253; OG IEEE 2013; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024); this may be aided by load generation and/or management (see Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). Patton defines this as running the software with as large of a load as possible (2006, p. 86), and Washizaki (2024, p. 5-9) seems to imply something similar; going past this "limit" is the realm of "stress testing" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9). Seeks to "discover problems … or reliability, stability, or robustness violations" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9). Good to use if the software may have "a large number of concurrent users" (IEEE, 2022, p. 45). Captured as part of "object load and timing" by Gerrard (2000, Tab. 2). See ISO 29119-1

Name: Localization Testing
Definition: Testing "a national or specific regional version of a product" (IEEE, 2017, p. 253; OG ISO/IEC 2008) to ensure it is "suitable for a specific user group" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)?
Notes: Related to internationalization testing, but can be done "separately from the translation process" (IEEE, 2017, p. 254)

Name: Loop Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5), Unit Testing? (implied by Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5), Structure-based Testing

Name: Loopback Testing
Definition: "Testing in which signals or data from a test device are input to a system or component, and results are returned to the test device for measurement or comparison" (IEEE, 2017, p. 257)
Notes: Related to "mechanism loopback" (IEEE, 2017, p. 270)?

Name: Low-Level Testing
Definition: Testing "with abstract preconditions, input data, expected results, postconditions, and actions (where applicable)" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: OG definition was about test cases, not a test approach

Name: Maintainability Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, pp. 5, 22; implied by its quality)
Definition: Testing "conducted to evaluate the degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a test item may be modified" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5; similar in ISO/IEC, 2023a) "by the intended maintainers" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), including through "corrections, improvements or adaptation of the product to changes in environment, and in requirements and functional specifications", as well as the "installation of updates and upgrades" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: Six categories: corrective, preventive, adaptive, additive, perfective, and emergency (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-4; "emergency" added in ISO/IEC/IEEE 14764 and mentioned in IEEE, 2017, p. 156); these may be sub-approaches

Name: Maintenance Testing
Definition: "Testing the changes to an operational system or the impact of a changed environment to an operational system" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Change-Related Testing?, Operational (Acceptance) Testing?
Notes: Related to portability testing and/or retesting?

Name: Malware Scanning
Definition: The "detect[ion] and remov[al of] malicious code received at an interface" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Static Analysis (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Interface Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)?

Name: Manual Testing
Definition: "Humans performing tests by entering information into a test item and verifying the results" (IEEE, 2022, p. 6)
Parent(s): Scripted Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 33)
Notes: "Inefficient, error prone and non-scalable" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5)

Name: Mathematical-based Testing
Definition: Testing based on "the test item's required behaviour, input space or output space" when they "can be described in sufficient detail" (IEEE, 2022, p. 36)
Parent(s): Automatic Testing (usually) (IEEE, 2022, p. 36)
Notes: Related to computation error testing from Patton (2006, p. 101)? See also ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-4

Name: MC/DC Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, p. 6; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing "based on demonstrating that a single Boolean [atomic (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)] condition within a decision can independently affect the outcome of the decision" (IEEE, 2022, p. 6; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 6, 22; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Synonym(s): Modified Condition Decision Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 6; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; with slash in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Condition Determination Testing, Modified Multiple Condition Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Metamorphic Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 6, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing "based on generating test cases based on existing test cases and metamorphic relations" (IEEE, 2022, p. 6; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Mutation Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15), Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 6, 22)
Notes: Test cases that pass and are "used as the basis of follow-up test cases" are called "source test cases" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). Metamorphic relations may be uncovered using regression analysis? Good to use when it is "difficult to calculate expected results" (IEEE, 2022, p. 45). See also Kanewala and Yueh Chen, 2019

Name: Mixed Entry Table Testing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising decision rules" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4) in a mixed entry table (IEEE, 2017, p. 278; OG ISO, 1984)
Parent(s): Decision Table Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 278; OG ISO, 1984)

Name: ML Model Testing
Definition: Testing "that focuses on the ability of an ML model to meet required ML functional performance criteria and non-functional criteria" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Domain-Specific Testing?
Notes: "ML functional performance" is defined in terms of "the functional correctness of an ML system" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), which is ambiguous and/or incorrect

Name: Model Verification
Parent(s): Static Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 17)

Name: Model-based Testing
Definition: Testing that uses "formal or semi-formal representations of the required behaviour of a … [test] item" to "generate test cases systematically and automatically" at "various levels of abstraction" (IEEE, 2022, p. 32)
Parent(s): Mathematical-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 36)
Notes: Models "vary in the degree of model formality" (such as Agile, semiformal, and formal models) (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-14). Good potential for automation/generation! See also Souza et al., 2017 (term used on p. 3) and Engström and Petersen, 2015

Name: Monkey Testing
Definition: Testing using "randomly generated test cases to cause the program to stop" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Parent(s): Ad Hoc Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), Random Testing?, Fuzz Testing?
Notes: Related to fuzz testing?

Name: Multiplayer Testing
Definition: "Testing to determine if many players can simultaneously interact with the … game world, … computer-controlled opponents, game servers, and … each other, [sic] as expected according to the game design" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: OG definition mentioned the "casino game world", but this can be generalized

Name: Multiple-Hit Decision Table Testing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising decision rules" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4) in a multiple-hit decision table (IEEE, 2017, p. 285; OG ISO, 1984)
Parent(s): Decision Table Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 285; OG ISO, 1984)

Name: Multi-User Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)

Name: Mutation Testing
Definition: Testing where "test cases are randomly generated … or … specifically designed" to detect "slightly modified version[s] of the SUT" called "mutants" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15) or "program mutations" (IEEE, 2017, p. 286)
Parent(s): Structure-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15), Fault-based Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-9)
Notes: Assumes that "that more complex but real faults will be found by looking for simple syntactic faults" and requires "many mutants … [to] be automatically generated and executed systematically"; can be used to assist fuzz and metamorphic testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15)

Name: Needs-Driven Testing
Definition: Testing that "tests why" the "system meets stakeholder needs"? (Firesmith, 2015, p. 33)

Name: Negative Testing
Definition: "Testing a component or system in a way for which it was not intended to be used" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024). "The application of boundary value concepts to scenario testing"? (IEEE, 2022, p. 40)
Parent(s): Security Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), Forcing Exception Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Boundary Value Analysis?, Scenario-based Testing? (IEEE, 2022, p. 40)
Synonym(s): Invalid Testing, Dirty Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: "Negative test cases can be derived from the state and event combinations that do not appear" in state models (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-20)

Name: Neighborhood Integration Testing
Definition: "Integration testing … [based on] the nodes that connect to a given node" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Integration Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: What does "node" mean in this context?

Name: Network Traffic Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 24)
Parent(s): Data Center Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 24)

Name: Neuron Coverage (Testing)?
Definition: Testing based on "the coverage of activated neurons in the neural network for a set of tests" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): ML Model Testing (implied by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Definition: Testing that "targets the validation of non-functional aspects (such as performance, [security,] usability, or reliability)" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8; IEEE, 2022, p. 21; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024) that tend to "constrain the technologies to be used in the implementation" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-4)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (although this seems over-zealous) (Gerrard, 2000, p. 9)
Notes: Hundreds of subapproaches that can be "performed at all test levels" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8). "Nonfunctional requirements" are also called "performance attributes" (IEEE, 2017, p. 293); what does this imply for the relationship between non-functional and performance testing? In constrast to functional testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 21)

Name: Offline MBT
Definition: "Model-based test[ing] … whereby test cases are generated into a repository for future execution" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Offline Testing, Model-based Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Offline Testing
Definition: Testing "in an environment without external interaction" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-6), or testing "whereby test cases are generated into a repository for future execution" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Sometimes spelled with a hyphen ("off-line"; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-6)

Name: Online MBT
Definition: "Model-based test[ing] … whereby test cases are generated and executed simultaneously" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Online Testing, Model-based Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Online Testing
Definition: Testing that "interacts with the real application environment" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-6), or testing "whereby test cases are generated and executed simultaneously" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Synonym(s): On-the-Fly Testing (implied by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Operational (Acceptance) Testing
Approach Category: Level (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from acceptance testing)
Definition: "Test[ing] to determine the correct installation, configuration and operation of a module and that it operates securely in the operational environment" (ISO/IEC, 2018) or "evaluate a system or component in its operational environment" (IEEE, 2017, p. 303), particularly "to determine if operations and/or systems administration staff can accept [it]" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; LambdaTest, 2024), Non-functional Testing (LambdaTest, 2024), Reliability Testing (likely incorrectly) (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-6)
Synonym(s): "Operational testing" and "operational acceptance testing" are treated as synonyms in this glossary, although there is sometimes a distinction (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30). Production Acceptance Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), OAT, OT (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)
Notes: Ensured by the use of TDD and ATDD (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-9)

Name: Operational Effectiveness Testing
Approach Category: Level (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from operational testing)
Parent(s): Operational Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Operational Suitability Testing
Approach Category: Level (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from operational testing)
Parent(s): Operational Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Outside-In Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 28)
Parent(s): Integration Testing? (see bottom-up and top-down testing)

Name: Outsourced Testing
Definition: "Testing performed by people who are not co-located with the project team and are not fellow employees" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Pair Testing
Definition: Testing "in which two team members simultaneously collaborate" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024); can be structured so that "one generates and runs the test cases[ and] the other observes and analyzes the testing process" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Parent(s): Ad Hoc Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), Development Testing (potentially?) (Gerrard, 2000, p. 11)
Notes: "Allows [for] generating test cases with broad and better test coverage" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14). Related to buddy testing?

Name: Pairwise Integration Testing
Definition: "Integration testing that targets pairs of components that work together as shown in a call graph" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Integration Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Pairwise Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 7, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing "in which test cases are designed to execute all possible discrete combinations of each pair of input parameters" (IEEE, 2022, p. 7) or "parameter-value pairs" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Combinatorial Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 7, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11), Specification-Based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 7; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Synonym(s): Orthogonal Array Testing (OAT) (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11), although this seems disputed by other sources
Notes: See ISO 29119-4

Name: Password Cracking
Definition: "Security attack[s] recovering secret passwords stored in a computer system or transmitted over a network" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Security Attacks (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Security Testing (implied by "transmitted over a network" in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: See NIST.IR.7298

Name: Path Testing
Definition: Testing that "aims to execute all entry-to-exit control flow paths in a SUT’s control flow graph" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Parent(s): Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; implied by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)
Notes: "Exhaustive path testing is generally not feasible because of loops" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), the exponential increase of possible paths with more branches (van Vliet, 2000, p. 421), and the "significant problem" of infeasible paths (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-5). The number of test cases should be at least "the number of linearly independent paths through a program's source code" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 4-2). Possibly involves "path analysis"

Name: Peer Reviews
Definition: "Review[s] of work products performed by peers [with similar abilities (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)] during development of the work products to identify defects for removal" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-13; OG [14], might be IEEE, 2017, p. 317?)
Parent(s): Reviews (IEEE, 2017, p. 317; Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Static Analysis? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-13)
Notes: "Often performed during development of the work products to identify defects for removal", "increase the quality of the work product", and "reduce cost by fixing defects as soon as possible" (IEEE, 2017, p. 317). Potentially a byproduct of pair programming (or else there is another type of "Pair Reviews") (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-14). See ISO 20246

Name: Penetration Testing
Approach Category: Type (inferred from security testing), Technique (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing that "tests a system in its final production environment" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 13-5) by "exploit[ing] security vulnerabilities (known or unknown) to gain unauthorized access" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), such as "submit[ting] malformed, malicious and random data to [its] entry points" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 13-5)
Parent(s): Security Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 13-4; implied by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Online Testing?, Operational Testing?
Notes: Should be conducted by security experts (Washizaki, 2024, p. 13-5). Related to fuzz testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 13-5)

Name: Performance Efficiency Testing
Definition: Testing to evaluate the "capability of a product to perform its functions within specified time and throughput parameters and be efficient in the use of resources under specified conditions" (ISO/IEC, 2023a; similar but less specific in IEEE, 2017, p. 319)
Parent(s): Performance-related Testing?, Performance Testing (implied by IEEE, 2017, p. 319), Reliability Testing, Dependability Testing (if it exists) (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: Resources can include devices, configurations, energy, or materials (ISO/IEC, 2023a). Related to the idea of "performance deficiency" (IEEE, 2017, p. 319)

Name: Performance Testing
Definition: Testing "conducted to evaluate the degree to which a test item accomplishes its designated functions within given constraints of time and other resources" (IEEE, 2022, p. 7; 2017, p. 320) or within "specified performance requirements" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), or to determine the performance efficiency of a component or system (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8; Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2), Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5, Tab. 2), Automated Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2),
Notes: Difference between this, performance efficiency testing, and performance-related testing? May be specific to "real-time constraints" (IEEE, 2022, p. 43). May be done by "us[ing] infrastructure/operations services" early on in the development process (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5)

Name: Performance-related Testing
Notes: Difference between this and performance testing?

Name: Pharming
Definition: "Security attack[s] intended to redirect a website's traffic to a fraudulent website without the user's knowledge or consent" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Security Attacks (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Physical Configuration Audits (PCAs)
Definition: "Audit[s] conducted to verify that a configuration item, as built, conforms to the technical documentation that defines it" (IEEE, 2017, p. 322)
Parent(s): Audits (IEEE, 2017, p. 250)

Name: Player Perspective Testing
Definition: "Testing done by testers from a player's perspective to validate player satisfaction" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Satisfaction Testing (if it exists) (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Playtesting
