Definition: "Testing of a game [performed] by players to identify failures and gather feedback" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Ad Hoc Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Portability Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, pp. 7, 22; implied by its quality)
Definition: Testing to evaluate the "capability of a product to be adapted to changes in its requirements, contexts of use, or system environment" (ISO/IEC, 2023a; similar in IEEE, 2022, p. 7; 2017, pp. 184, 329; and Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Synonym(s): Flexibility Testing (ISO/IEC, 2023a); Transportability Testing (implied by IEEE, 2017, p. 329)
Notes: Related to co-existence and installability testing, as well as adaptability and replaceability testing (if they exist) (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024) and potentially compatibility testing, and can improve user assistance and interaction capability (ISO/IEC, 2023a) "Can be measured either as the extent to which a product can be used by additional types of users to achieve additional types of goals … or by a capability to be modified to support adaptation for new types of users", etc. (ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Post-Deployment Monitoring
Definition: The use of "retain[ed] automated tests" (Gerrard, 2000, p. 13) "in a production environment" (p. 15)
Parent(s): Automated Testing (Gerrard, 2000, pp. 13, 15), Performance Testing (implied by p. 15), Regression Testing

Name: Post-Release Testing
Definition: "Testing to ensure that the release is performed correctly and the application can be deployed" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Online Testing?, Operational Testing?

Name: Power Testing?
Definition: Testing "based on power consumption and battery failure" (IEEE, 2022, p. 43); term is original
Parent(s): Performance-related Testing

Name: Prioritization Testing
Definition: Testing that "schedule[s] test cases to increase the rate [and likelihood] of fault detection, … the coverage of code under test, and … reliability" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Notes: What does "schedule" mean in this context?

Name: Privacy Testing
Definition: Testing that "assess[es] the security and privacy of users’ personal data to prevent local attacks" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)
Notes: Assesses policies and profile/data management (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10); seems to overlap with IEEE's definition of security testing

Name: Procedure Testing
Definition: Testing "conducted to evaluate whether procedural instructions for interacting with a test item or using its outputs meet user requirements and support the purpose of their use" (IEEE, 2022, p. 7; 2017, p. 337; OG IEEE, 2013)
Parent(s): Functional Suitability Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 7; 2017, p. 337; OG IEEE, 2013)

Name: Process-Driven Scripting
Definition: Testing "where scripts are structured into scenarios which represent use cases of the software under test" and "can be parameterized with test data" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Scripted Testing, Scenario Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Processor-in-the-Loop Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)
Parent(s): System Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)

Name: Production Acceptance Testing
Approach Category: Level (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from acceptance testing)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)
Synonym(s): Operational Acceptance Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), PAT (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Production Verification Testing
Approach Category: Level (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; inferred from acceptance testing)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Online Testing?, Operational Testing?

Name: Qualification Testing
Definition: "Testing … to demonstrate that a software product meets its specifications and is ready for use in its target environment or integration with its containing system" (IEEE, 2017, p. 360; OG ISO/IEC, 2008)
Notes: "Conducted by the developer and witnessed by the acquirer (as appropriate)" (IEEE, 2017, p. 360). Including "software" in its definition may be incorrect, since hardware qualification testing exists (Firesmith, 2015, p. 21). Difference between this and qualification operational testing?

Name: Qualification Operational Testing
Parent(s): Operational Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30), Qualification Testing?
Notes: Difference between this and qualification testing?

Name: Quick Testing
Definition: Testing "in which a very small test suite is selected and executed" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Parent(s): Ad Hoc Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Notes: "Guarantees that no failure can be experienced because of SUT components that are not fully operational" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), but this is not elaborated on

Name: Random Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 7, 22, 36; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Practice? (inferred from mathematical-based testing)
Definition: Testing "based on generating test cases to exercise randomly selected test item inputs" (IEEE, 2022, p. 7) which can be "generated based on an operational profile" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 7, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Usage-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15; implied by use operational profile by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Mathematical-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 36)
Notes: Often used in automated testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12) and reliability testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 439). Implied to be related to statistical testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15)

Name: Rapid Prototyping Testing
Definition: Testing performed on prototypes developed "early in the development process to permit early feedback and analysis" (IEEE, 2017, p. 365)
Parent(s): Lifecycle-based Testing

Name: Reactive Testing
Definition: "Testing that dynamically responds to the behavior of the test object and to test results being obtained" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (implied by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: What does "responds" mean in this context?

Name: Recovery Testing
Parent(s): Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: Difference between this and disaster/recovery testing?

Name: Recovery Testing
Definition: Testing of "software restart capabilities after a system crash or other disaster" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9) that ensures it is "restor[ed] … to a state in which it can perform required functions" (IEEE, 2017, p. 370)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), Usability Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10), Dynamic Testing? (implied by Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)
Notes: May be done through simulations (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-28). Difference between this and disaster/recovery testing?

Name: Regression Testing
Definition: The "selective retesting of a system or component to verify that modifications [to a test item or to its operational environment (IEEE, 2022, p. 8)] have not caused unintended effects", specifically in the areas of "functionality, reliability [and] performance", and have "not introduced additional defects" (IEEE, 2017, p. 372), primarily "in unmodified parts of the test item" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Functional Testing, Non-functional Testing, Continuous Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8), Change-Related Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Development Testing (can be) (Gerrard, 2000, p. 11)
Notes: "Does not test that the modification works correctly"; this is "retesting" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8; also described as separate in Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5). Interesting to note it is sometimes described as such (Washizaki, 2024, pp. 7-5 to 7-6; IEEE, 2017, p. 372), maybe just in the sense of "testing again"? Should be part of any test strategy and its level should be "based on a knowledge of the risks associated with developers making changes" (IEEE, 2022, p. 23), although it can be applied to any level (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8), and "play[s] an important role in software engineering operations" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5) and "maintenance" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 7-5). Can be supported by tools, such as "tinderboxes" (IEEE, 2017, p. 478)

Name: Regulatory Acceptance Testing
Approach Category: Level (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from acceptance testing)
Definition: "Testing performed to determine the compliance of the test object" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)
Notes: Difference between this and acceptance testing?

Name: Reliability Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, pp. 8, 22; 2017, p. 375; implied by its quality)
Definition: Testing that evaluates the "capability of a product to perform specified functions under specified conditions for a specified period of time without interruptions and failures" (ISO/IEC, 2023a); can be mesaured as "the frequency with which failures occur" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8; 2013, p. 5) or the "probability that software will not cause the failure of a system" (IEEE, 2017, p. 425)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9; Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2), Security Testing (implied by IEEE, 2017, p. 404), Smoke Testing, Automated Testing, Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)
Synonym(s): Soak Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2), Dependability Testing (if it exists, although this has a wider scope) (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: Often uses statistical models of user behaviour, reliability growth models (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), and/or random testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 439) and may be facilitated by DevOps (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9) such as "infrastructure/operations services", which can be done early on in the development process (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5). Can be done using "the test-retest method, the alternative form method, the split-halves method and the internal consistency method" (verify this applies to software) (Washizaki, 2024, p. 18-14)

Name: Requirements-based Testing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising atomic requirements" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 8, 22), Risk-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 20)
Synonym(s): Software Quality Evaluations? (IEEE, 2017, p. 425; OG ISO/IEC, 2014)
Notes: May involve "requirements analysis"

Name: Requirements-driven Testing
Definition: Testing that "verifies" the "system meets system requirements" (Firesmith, 2015, p. 33)
Notes: Difference between this and requirements-based testing?

Name: Response-Time Testing
Definition: Testing that evaluates the "capability of a product to perform its specified function under specified conditions so that the response time … meet[s] the requirements" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Parent(s): Performance Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9); Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22); Time Behaviour Testing? (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: Good to use if the software may have "a large number of concurrent users" (IEEE, 2022, p. 45). Captured as part of "object load and timing" by Gerrard (2000, Tab. 2)

Name: Retesting (or "Re-testing" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024))
Definition: "Testing performed to check that modifications made to correct a fault have successfully removed the fault" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8; similar in 2017, p. 386 and Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Change-Related Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Synonym(s): Confirmation Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 8; 2017, p. 386; used by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Should be part of any test strategy and its level should be "based on a knowledge of the risks associated with developers making changes" (IEEE, 2022, p. 23) and "play[s] an important role in software  engineering operations" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5). "In most cases, the original test cases associated with the fixed code are used for retesting [as prescribed by IEEE (2017, p. 386)], but they are sometimes supplemented by new test cases that provide improved coverage" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35)

Name: Reviews
Definition: "Process[es] or meeting[s] during which a software product is presented to project personnel, managers, users, customers, user representatives, or other interested parties for comment or approval" (IEEE, 2017, p. 388) "to detect defects or to provide improvements" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Static Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 17, 25, 28; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Gerrard, 2000, p. 12; implied by Fig. 4), Static Analysis? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-13)
Notes: "Can identify issues early in development or even before a component is designed" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-13; implied by Gerrard, 2000, pp. 9-10). See also ISO/IEC 20246

Name: Risk-based Testing
Definition: Testing "in which the management, selection, prioritization, and use of testing activities and resources are consciously based on corresponding types and levels of analysed risk" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8; 2017, p. 394; OG 2013)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing? (IEEE, 2022, p. 18)
Notes: Recommended technique for "choosing the subset of possible tests that are most likely to uncover issues of interest" (IEEE, 2022, p. 18) and helps to "design[] effective tests to find faults" without "worry[ing] about doing 'too little' testing" (Gerrard, 2000). May involve "risk analysis". See the ISO/IEC 25000 SQuaRE family of standards

Name: Robustness Testing
Definition: Testing the "degree to which a system or component can function correctly in the presence of invalid inputs or stressful environmental conditions" (IEEE, 2017, p. 394)
Parent(s): Boundary-Value Analysis (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Synonym(s): Fault Tolerance Testing (implied by Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Related to error/fault tolerance (IEEE, 2017, p. 394) and potentially stress testing?

Name: Role-based Reviews
Definition: Reviews "in which a work product is evaluated from the perspective of different stakeholders" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Reviews (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Scenario Testing?

Name: Safety Demonstrations
Definition: "Bod[ies] of evidence and rationale that show[] an item is justified as being safe within allowed limits on risk" (IEEE, 2017, p. 397; OG ISO/IEC, 2011)

Name: Sandwich Testing
Parent(s): Integration Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7)

Name: Scalability Testing
Definition: Testing the "capability of a product to handle growing or shrinking workloads or to adapt its capacity to handle variability" (ISO/IEC, 2023a; similar in Gerrard and Thompson, 2002)
Parent(s): Portability Testing (ISO/IEC, 2023a); Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Notes: "Particularly important in distributed or high-performance systems" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9) and may be done by "us[ing] infrastructure/operations services" early on in the development process (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-5). Washizaki seems to define it as usability testing (2024, p. 5-9), despite correctly defining "scalability" (2024, p. 5-5). Related to elasticity testing?

Name: Scenario Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 22; 2017, p. 400; OG 2013; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Definition: Testing "based on exercising sequences of interactions between the test item and other systems," including users (IEEE, 2022, p. 9), that is "the SUT’s behavioral aspects" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Model-based Testing (implied by Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-10)
Synonym(s): User Scenario Testing, Use Case Testing (although the latter is listed separately by IEEE (2022, p. 22)) (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: "Often used with test automation harnesses" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)

Name: Scenario-based Reviews
Definition: Testing "to determine [a work product's] ability to address specific scenarios" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Reviews (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Scenario Testing

Name: Scripted Testing
Definition: "Testing performed based on a documented test script" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9; 2017, p. 403; OG 2013) or "written instructions in a test case" (IEEE, 2017, p. 403; OG 2013)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 403; OG 2013), Manual Testing (usually) (IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 33; 2017, p. 403; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Automatic Testing ("typically requires more detail") (IEEE, 2022, p. 33; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: "Helps achieve required test coverage levels" (IEEE, 2022, p. 33)

Name: Security Attacks
Definition: "Attempt[s] to gain unauthorized access to a component or system, resources, information, or … to compromise system integrity" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Security Testing, Attacks, Integrity Testing (if it exists)
Notes: "An example of a security attack would be to block access to software libraries" (IEEE, 2022, p. 34). Could be malicious or as a genuine part of testing; see note on attacks. See NIST.IR.7298

Name: Security Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 22, 26-27; 2017, p. 405; OG 2013; implied by its quality)
Definition: Testing that evaluates the "capability of a product to protect information and data [including data in transmission (ISO/IEC, 2023a)] so that persons or other products have the degree of data access appropriate to their types and levels of authorization, and to defend against attack patterns by malicious actors" (ISO/IEC, 2023a; similar in IEEE, 2022, p. 9; Washizaki, 2024, pp. 5-9, 13-14)
Parent(s): Reliability Testing, Dependability Testing (if it exists) (ISO/IEC, 2023a), Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5, Tab. 2), Non-functional Testing, Functionality Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2), System Testing? (implied by Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)
Notes: Verifies "confidentiality, integrity, and availability" and usually includes negative testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9). Good to use when the software will be widely available (IEEE, 2022, p. 45)

Name: Session-based Testing
Definition: Testing "in which test activities are planned as test sessions" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Sign Change Coverage (Testing?)
Definition: Testing of "the coverage of neurons activated with both positive and negative activation values in a neural network for a set of tests" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): ML Model Testing

Name: Sign-Sign Coverage (Testing?)
Definition: Testing of "the coverage achieved if by changing the sign of each neuron it can be shown to individually cause one neuron in the next layer to change sign while all other neurons in the next layer do not change sign for a set of tests" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): ML Model Testing
Notes: See ISO 29119-11

Name: Similarity-based Prioritization Testing
Definition: Testing that prioritizes test cases "starting from those most dissimilar according to a predefined distance function" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Parent(s): Prioritization Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)

Name: Single-Hit Decision Table
Definition: Testing "based on exercising decision rules" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4) in a single-hit decision table (IEEE, 2017, p. 415; OG ISO, 1984)
Parent(s): Decision Table Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 175; OG ISO, 1984)

Name: Site Acceptance Testing
Approach Category: Level (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from acceptance testing)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)

Name: Smoke Testing
Definition: Testing that "ensures that the SUT's core functionalities behave properly" and "the SUT is operational before the planned testing begins" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Ad Hoc Testing, Quick Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), Unscripted Testing (implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14 and Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Automated Testing (often) (Gerrard, 2000, p. 13), Offline Testing?
Synonym(s): Build Verification Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), Sanity Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Intake Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Confidence Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Should be prioritized in the presence of "severe time pressure" (Gerrard, 2000, p. 13). "Prevents failures because of the test environment" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14). Seems to be implied to be the responsibility of DevOps (Washizaki, 2024, p. 6-9)

Name: Software Design Audits
Definition: "Review[s] of … software product[s] to determine compliance with requirements, standards, and contractual documents" (IEEE, 2017, p. 420)
Parent(s): Audits, Reviews (IEEE, 2017, p. 420)
Notes: Is this specific to the software's design, or to the software itself?

Name: Software Qualification Testing
Definition: "Testing performed on completed, integrated software to provide evidence for compliance with software requirements" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Safety Testing (implied by Knüvener Mackert GmbH, 2022, pp. 36-37), System Testing?, Dynamic Testing?
Notes: Difference between this and system testing?

Name: Software-in-the-Loop Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)
Definition: "Testing performed using real software in a simulated environment or with experimental hardware" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): System Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23), Dynamic Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Integration Testing? (Knüvener Mackert GmbH, 2022, p. 153)
Synonym(s): SiL Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), SIL Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)

Name: SoS Integration Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)
Parent(s): System Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)

Name: SoS Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)
Parent(s): System Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)

Name: Specification-based Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Souza et al., 2017, p. 3; implied by IEEE, 2022, pp. 2-4, 6-9)
Definition: "Testing in which the principal test basis is the external inputs and outputs of the test item" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9; 2017, p. 431) or its specification (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024) that "select[s] a few test cases from the input domain that can detect specific categories of faults" (Washizaki, 2024, pp. 5-10 to 5-11)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 17)
Synonym(s): Black-Box Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; IEEE, 2022, p. 9; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; IEEE, 2017, p. 431; van Vliet, 2000, p. 399), Domain Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10), Closed-Box Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 9; 2017, p. 431), Input Domain-Based Testing (implied by Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-8), Functional Testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 399; implied by IEEE, 2017, p. 431)
Notes: Should be done before structure-based testing to avoid bias towards "test cases based on how the module works" (Patton, 2006, p. 113). Difference between this and functional testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 399; IEEE, 2017, p. 431; Souza et al., 2017, p. 3)? Umar (2020) has more synonyms

Name: Spike Testing
Definition: "Testing to determine the ability of a system to recover from sudden bursts of peak loads and return to a steady state" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Spiral Testing
Definition: Testing "performed iteratively until the software is complete" alongside other phases of development (IEEE, 2017, p. 432)
Parent(s): Lifecycle-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-5; OG [2, 3, 10]), Risk-based Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-6; OG [3]), Continuous Testing

Name: SQL Injection
Definition: "A type of code injection in the structured query language (SQL)" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Code Injection (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: State Transition Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing "derived to cover the states and transitions" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12), defined as "change[s] from one state to another … or the same state" (IEEE, 2017, p. 484; OG ISO/IEC, 1995), "in a state model" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 22; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Model-based Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-10; implied by IEEE, 2022, p. 9 and Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Could be facilitated by a state diagram (IEEE, 2017, p. 438). Washizaki implies the SUT is represented by a finite-state machine (2024, p. 5-12). See also Patton, 2006, pp. 79-87

Name: Statement Testing
Approach Category: Technique (IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 22; IEEE, 2017, p. 438; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: Testing "based on exercising executable statements" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9) by "forc[ing the] execution of individual statements in a test item" (IEEE, 2017, p. 439; OG IEEE, 2013)
Parent(s): Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)

Name: Static Analysis
Definition: The "process of evaluating a system or component based on its form, structure, content, or documentation" (IEEE, 2017, p. 439) that "involves the use of tools to detect anomalies in code or documents without execution" (IEEE, 2022, p. 18)
Parent(s): Static Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 17, 25, 28; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 4, p. 12)
Notes: See also ISO/IEC 20246

Name: Static Testing
Definition: "Testing in which a test item is examined against a set of quality or other criteria without the test item being executed" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9; 2017, p. 440; OG 2013)
Notes: "Helps form an optimal test strategy" (IEEE, 2022, p. 21), "can be performed anywhere in the life cycle" (IEEE, 2022, p. 17), including "prior to dynamic testing[,] and can find defects before test execution becomes possible" (IEEE, 2022, p. 21). Not always considered "testing" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-2). See also ISO/IEC 20246

Name: Statistical Testing
Parent(s): Usage-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15)
Notes: "Often provide[s] a snapshot of the more troublesome areas of the software product under examination" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-8). "Usage-based statistical testing is applied more during the acceptance testing stage" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15); how to track this? Implied to be related to random testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15)

Name: Stress Testing
Definition: Testing of "the SUT [at or (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)] beyond its capabilities [done] by generating a load greater than what the system is expected to handle" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9) or providing insufficient resource availability (IEEE, 2022, p. 9; 2017, p. 442; OG 2013), "such as access to memory or servers" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Performance Efficiency Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 9; 2017, p. 442), Performance Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Boundary Condition Testing (Patton, 2006, p. 86; implied by IEEE, 2017, p. 442), Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)

Name: Structure-based Testing
Approach Category: Technique (Washizaki, 2024, pp. 5-10, 5-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; implied by IEEE, 2022, pp. 2, 4, 6, 9)
Definition: Testing "derived from an examination of the structure[, internal contents or implementation (IEEE, 2017, p. 199)] of the test item" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 17; 2017, p. 444), Static Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Synonym(s): White-Box Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 9; 2017, pp. 443-444; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Patton, 2006, p. 55), Glass-Box Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 9; 2017, pp. 443-444; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, p. 439), Structural Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 9; 2017, pp. 443-444; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Code-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; implied by Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-8), Clear-Box Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Patton, 2006, p. 55)
Notes: "Can be performed at different levels (such as code development, code inspection, or unit testing)" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13). Hamburg and Mogyorodi (2024) and Umar (2020) have more synonyms; it seems like "structure-based testing" is specific to dynamic testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 444) but "structural testing" isn't (p. 443)

Name: Structured Scripting
Definition: "Scripting … that builds and utilizes a library of reusable (parts of) scripts" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Scripted Testing

Name: Structured Walkthroughs
Definition: "Systematic examination[s] of the requirements, design, or implementation of a system, or any part of it, by qualified personnel" (IEEE, 2017, p. 444; OG ISO/IEC, 2015)
Parent(s): Walkthroughs, Static Testing

Name: Subsystem Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)
Parent(s): System Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23), Unit Testing? (seems incorrect) (implied by Firesmith, 2015, p. 28)

Name: Summative Evaluation(s)
Definition: "Evaluation[s] designed and used to gather conclusions about the quality of a component or system, especially when a substantial part of it has completed design" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): System Testing?

Name: Symbolic Execution
Definition: Testing "in which program execution is simulated using symbols … and program outputs are expressed as logical or mathematical expressions involving these symbols" (IEEE, 2017, p. 451)
Parent(s): Static Testing, Static Analysis?, Correctness Testing?

Name: Syntax Testing
Definition: Testing based on "the SUT specifications in a formal language" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Functional Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11), Static Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-10), Model-based Testing (implied by Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-10)
Notes: "Permits automatic derivation of functional test cases[,] … provides an oracle for checking test results" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11), and "permit[s] desired properties of the specified software to be proved" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-10). Test cases can be generated from these formal requirements (e.g., BDD scenarios and state models), but "determining an expected result is not always possible" and may require "additional business domain expertise" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-20). See also (Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, pp. 448-449; Intana et al., 2020, p. 260)

Name: System Integration Testing
Definition: Testing the "progressive assembling of system components into the whole system" (IEEE, 2017, p. 454; OG ISO/IEC, 2015)
Parent(s): Integration Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), System Testing (Firestorm, 2015, p. 23)

Name: System Qualification Testing
Definition: "Testing performed on the completed, integrated system of software components, hardware components, and mechanics to provide evidence for compliance with system requirements and that the complete system is ready for delivery" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): System Testing?, Dynamic Testing?
Notes: Difference between this and system testing?

Name: System Testing
Approach Category: Level (IEEE, 2022, pp. 12, 20-22, 26-27; 2017, p. 467; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: "Testing conducted on a complete, integrated system to evaluate [its] compliance with its specified requirements" (IEEE, 2017, p. 456; OG 2012; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), usually in regards to "non-functional system requirements", and verify its behaviour (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7).
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, p. 9)

Name: Systems Integration Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted on multiple complete, integrated systems to evaluate their ability to communicate successfully with each other and to meet the overall integrated systems' specified requirements" (IEEE, 2017, p. 457)
Parent(s): Integration Testing

Name: Technical Reviews (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-14)
Definition: The "systematic evaluation of a software product by a team of qualified personnel that examines the suitability of the software product for its intended use and identifies discrepancies from specifications and standards" (IEEE, 2017, p. 463; OG IEEE, 2008), often done "at logical transition points in a system life cycle" (IEEE, 2017, p. 463; OG IEEE, 2014)
Parent(s): Formal Reviews (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: "Can … be more focused and address a specific project phase" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 12-14; OG [24]). More types given by Washizaki (2024, p. 12-14)

Name: Technical Testing? (implied by "technical requirements"; IEEE, 2017, p. 463)
Definition: Testing "requirements relating to the technology and environment, for the development, maintenance, support and execution of the software" (IEEE, 2017, p. 463)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing?
Notes: Includes the "programming language, testing tools, operating systems, database technology and user interface technologies" (IEEE, 2017, p. 463)

Name: Think Aloud Usability Testing
Definition: Testing "where test participants share their thoughts with the moderator and observers by thinking aloud while they solve usability test tasks" which helps the testers "understand the test participant" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Usability Testing

Name: Threshold Coverage (Testing?)
Definition: Testing based on "the coverage of neurons exceeding a threshold activation value in a neural network for a set of tests" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): ML Model Testing

Name: Top-Down Testing
Definition: Integration testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7) that "starts with the highest‐level component[s] … and proceeds through progressively lower‐levels" (IEEE, 2017, p. 479)
Parent(s): Integration Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7)
Notes: Difference between this as integration testing vs. not (as in Firesmith, 2015, p. 28)?

Name: Tours
Definition: Testing that is quite general and "guides testers through the paths of an application like a tour guide leads a tourist through the landmarks of a big city" (IEEE, 2022, p. 34), or that is exploratory yet "organized around a special focus" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Exploratory Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 34; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Experience-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 34)

Name: Transaction Testing
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5, Tab. 2), Functionality Testing, System Testing, Functional Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)

Name: Transaction Verification
Parent(s): Smoke Testing, Test Browsing, Static Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)

Name: t-Wise Testing
Definition: Testing that "considers every possible combination of [some] t input" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Parent(s): All Combinations Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Notes: "More than one pair is derived (i.e., by including higher-level combinations)" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)

Name: Unit Testing
Approach Category: Level (IEEE, 2022, pp. 12, 20-22, 26-27; 2017, p. 467; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-6; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Definition: "Testing of individual hardware or software components" (IEEE, 2012, p. 8; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024) or of "individual routines and modules" (IEEE, 2017, p. 490)
Parent(s): Construction Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 4-7), Automated Testing (often) (Washizaki, 2024, p. 4-14), Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, p. 9)
Synonym(s): Component Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 12-13; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Firestorm, 2015, p. 22; Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, p. 444), Module Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Patton, 2006, p. 109)
Notes: "The terms module, component, and unit [sic] are often used interchangeably or defined to be subelements of one another in different ways depending upon the context" with no standardized relationship (IEEE, 2017, p. 82) but a distinction is sometimes made; for example, "components differ from classical modules for being re-used in different contexts independently of their development" (Baresi and Pezzè, 2006, p. 107). See also Engström and Petersen, 2015

Name: Unscripted Testing
Definition: "Testing in which the tester's actions are not prescribed by written instructions in a test case" (IEEE, 2022, p. 15; 2017, p. 490; OG IEEE, 2013)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 15; 2017, p. 490)

Name: Usability Test Script(ing)
Definition: The creation/use of "a document specifying a sequence of actions for the execution of a usability test" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Usability Testing; Structured Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: Usability Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, pp. 22, 26-27; implied by its type)
Definition: Testing that "evaluate[s] how easy it is for ['specified users' to use and (IEEE, 2017, p. 492; OG ISO/IEC, 2013)] learn to use the software" by testing functionality (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10, IEEE, 2017, p. 493), documentation, and/or recovery (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing, System Testing, Manual Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)
Synonym(s): Interaction Capability Testing (ISO/IEC, 2023a), Fitness-for-Use Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 493), Human-Computer Interaction Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)
Notes: Related to acceptance testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 439) and potentially reusability (IEEE, 2017, p. 492), but this relation may just be syntactic 😅

Name: Usability Walkthroughs
Definition: "Usability evaluation[s] in which one or more evaluators step through a scenario playing the role of a user and identifying usability problems associated with successful completion of the scenario[s]" (IEEE, 2017, p. 493; OG ISO/IEC, 2010)
Parent(s): Usability Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 493), Walkthroughs
Notes: "Evaluators can include usability specialists, developers, [and/or] end users" (IEEE, 2017, p. 493)

Name: Usage-based Testing
Definition: Testing that "usually rel[ies] on a usage model or profiles" in the context of "the actual operational environment" and "usage by the target stakeholder" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15)
Parent(s): Online Testing?
Notes: May involve the development/implementation of an "operational profile" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)

Name: User Acceptance Testing
Approach Category: Level (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Firesmith, 2015, p. 30; inferred from acceptance testing)
Definition: "A type of acceptance testing performed to determine if intended users accept the system" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024; Firesmith, 2015, p. 30)
Notes: Also mentioned by Washizaki (2024, p. 6-13)

Name: User Story Testing
Definition: Testing "in which test conditions are the acceptance criteria of user stories" or "requirement[s] consisting of one sentence … capturing the functionality a user needs, the reason behind it, any non-functional criteria, and … acceptance criteria" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024), Requirements-based Testing, User-based Testing?

Name: User Surveys
Definition: "Evaluation[s] whereby a representative sample of users are asked to report subjective evaluation into a questionnaire based on their experience in using a component or system" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Usability Testing, User-based Testing?

Name: User-Agent Based Testing
Definition: "Testing in which a test client is used to switch the user agent string and identify itself as a different client while executing test suites" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Could be used in security testing

Name: User-based Evaluations
Definition: "Evaluation[s] that involve[] representative users performing tasks with the system … focused on usability[,] … efficiency, effectiveness, [and/or] user satisfaction" (IEEE, 2017, p. 498; OG ISO/IEC, 2016)
Parent(s): Usability Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 498), Acceptance Testing?

Name: V-Model Testing (Firesmith, 2015, p. 29)
Definition: Testing that occurs alongside the phases of the waterfall model in a "layered and phased nature" (Gerrard, 2000, p. 9)
Parent(s): Waterfall Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-6; OG [3]; Firesmith, 2015, p. 29), Lifecycle-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-5; OG [2, 3, 10]), W-Model Testing? (implied by Gerrard, 2000, p. 9)
Notes: See also Washizaki (2024, p. 10-6; OG [3])

Name: Validation Testing
Definition: "Test[ing] to determine whether an implemented system fulfils its specified requirements" (IEEE, 2017, p. 499; ISO/IEC, 2015)
Notes: OG definition was about a specific test, not a test approach

Name: Verification Testing
Definition: Testing to determine whether a system fulfils "its specified requirements at a particular stage of its development" (IEEE, 2017, p. 504; ISO/IEC, 2015)
Notes: This seems to conflate the definition of "verification" with "validation"

Name: Visual Browser Validation
Parent(s): Usability Testing, Manual Testing, Static/Dynamic Testing? (Gerrard, 2000, Tab. 2)

Name: Visual Testing
Definition: "Testing that uses image recognition to interact with GUI objects" (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: See ISO 29119-11

Name: Volume Testing
Definition: Testing to assess "the SUT’s internal storage limitations and its ability to exchange data and information" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9) or "process specified volumes of data (usually at or near maximum specified capacity)" (IEEE, 2017, p. 508; OG 2013)
Parent(s): Performance Efficiency Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 508; OG 2013), Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), Dynamic Testing (Gerrard, 2000, Fig. 5)

Name: W-Model Testing
Definition: The combination of "static testing of early document or code deliverables and dynamic test stages of software deliverables" (Gerrard, 2000, p. 9)
Parent(s): Waterfall Testing? (implied by Firesmith, 2015, p. 29 based on V-model testing)
Synonym(s): Since only dynamic testing is considered for this research, the in-scope part of W-model testing is equivalent to V-model testing

Name: Walkthroughs
Definition: Evaluations "in which a designer or programmer leads members of the development team and other interested parties through a segment of documentation or code, and the participants ask questions and make comments about possible errors, violation of development standards, and other problems" (IEEE, 2017, p. 508; similar in Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Parent(s): Static Analysis (IEEE, 2017, p. 508), Formal Reviews, Reviews (Hamburg and Mogyorodi, 2024)
Notes: Sometimes spelled with a hyphen ("walk-through"; IEEE, 2017, pp. 133, 439, 508). See ISO 20246

Name: Waterfall Testing
Definition: Testing performed in the context of the waterfall model; i.e., after implementation but before installation and checkout, either strictly sequentially (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-5) or "possibly with overlap but with little or no iteration" (IEEE, 2017, p. 509)
Parent(s): Lifecycle-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 10-5; OG [2, 3, 10]; Firesmith, 2015, p. 29)

Notes: See also the ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119 series (especially 29119-4); 29119-2 provides more information on test processes
See also ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology -— Vocabulary
Compare ISO/IEC TR 19759:2016 to SWEBOK
Investigate convertibility/functional size measurement (IEEE, 2017, p. 103)
